name: Ethics and Code of Conduct
description: Covers civil service values, integrity, transparency, accountability, conflict of interest, and the Code of Conduct for Public Officers.

subcategories.name: Code of Conduct
subcategories.description: Rules and regulations governing the conduct of public officers, including asset declaration, gifts, and prohibitions.

questions.question: Which Nigerian body is responsible for enforcing the Code of Conduct for public officers?
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct Bureau (CCB) is mandated by the Constitution to enforce ethical standards for public officers.

questions.question: According to the Code of Conduct, public officers are prohibited from:
questions.explanation: The Constitution prohibits public officers from maintaining foreign bank accounts.

questions.question: The Code of Conduct Bureau is established under which section of the 1999 Constitution?
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct Bureau is established under the Fifth Schedule of the 1999 Constitution.

questions.question: Which of the following is prohibited under the Code of Conduct for public officers?
options: Engaging in private business without approval
questions.explanation: Public officers are prohibited from engaging in private business without appropriate approval.

questions.question: What is the main role of the Code of Conduct Tribunal (CCT)?
options: Prosecution of public officers for breaches of the Code of Conduct
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct Tribunal prosecutes cases of public officers who breach the Code of Conduct.

questions.question: Which type of gift is prohibited for public officers under the Code of Conduct?
questions.explanation: Public officers must not accept gifts related to the performance of their official duties.

questions.question: Which body is empowered to prosecute public officers for violations of the Code of Conduct?
questions.explanation: The CCT prosecutes cases of public officers who breach the Code of Conduct.

questions.question: Which law guides the Code of Conduct for Public Officers in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: The 1999 Constitution’s Fifth Schedule provides the Code of Conduct for Public Officers.

questions.question: What is the penalty for violating the Code of Conduct as determined by the CCT?
options: Dismissal or disqualification from public office
questions.explanation: The CCT may dismiss, suspend, or disqualify public officers from holding office if found guilty.

questions.question: Which constitutional provision empowers the CCT to try cases of misconduct?
questions.explanation: The Fifth Schedule of the 1999 Constitution empowers the CCT to try misconduct cases.

questions.question: What must public officers submit to the CCB within three months of assuming office?
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct requires all public officers to declare their assets within three months of assumption of office.

questions.question: Which body can disqualify public officers from holding office due to ethical violations?
questions.explanation: The CCT can disqualify public officers from holding office due to breaches of the Code of Conduct.

questions.question: Which constitutional principle underpins the Code of Conduct for Public Officers?
questions.explanation: Accountability and transparency form the constitutional basis for the Code of Conduct.

questions.question: Which body can recommend removal of a public officer due to unethical conduct?
questions.explanation: The CCT can recommend removal of public officers found guilty of unethical conduct.

questions.question: Which body investigates breaches of ethical conduct relating to asset declarations?
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct Bureau investigates breaches relating to asset declarations.

questions.question: Which body enforces penalties for non-compliance with ethical rules for public officers?
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct Tribunal enforces penalties for violations of ethical rules.

questions.question: Which body can recommend removal of a public officer due to unethical conduct?
questions.explanation: The CCT can recommend removal of public officers found guilty of unethical conduct.

questions.question: What is the foundation of the Code of Conduct for public officers?
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct emphasizes serving the public interest above personal interests.

subcategories.name: Civil Service Values
subcategories.description: Core values guiding civil servants, including integrity, impartiality, accountability, and transparency.

questions.question: According to the Civil Service Handbook, civil servants must uphold which of the following values?
questions.explanation: The handbook emphasizes secrecy, efficiency, and loyalty as core values of civil servants.

questions.question: Civil servants are expected to maintain political neutrality. What does this mean?
options: They can openly campaign for political parties
They must serve all administrations equally, regardless of political party
They must reject orders from ruling governments
They are not allowed to vote
questions.explanation: Political neutrality requires civil servants to serve any government of the day equally, without political bias.

questions.question: Which ethical obligation of public servants?
questions.explanation: Civil servants must remain loyal to the Nigerian Constitution and the government of the day.

questions.question: Which value requires that civil servants provide unbiased service to all citizens?
questions.explanation: Impartiality ensures civil servants serve all citizens without discrimination or favoritism.

questions.question: Which ethical principle requires honesty and fairness in all official dealings?
questions.explanation: Integrity requires honesty and fairness in all official dealings.

questions.question: Which of these promotes public trust in governance?
questions.explanation: Transparency builds public trust by ensuring government activities are open and accessible.

questions.question: Which ethical principle requires civil servants to put public interest above personal gain?
questions.explanation: Selflessness ensures civil servants act in the public interest and not for personal enrichment.

questions.question: Which civil service value requires that civil servants use resources effectively and avoid waste?
questions.explanation: Efficiency ensures that civil servants make the best use of resources and avoid waste.

questions.question: Which ethical principle is violated when a civil servant uses official time for personal business?
questions.explanation: Efficiency requires that official time is used productively and not for personal business.

questions.question: Which ethical principle requires civil servants to provide services without discrimination?
questions.explanation: Impartiality means providing fair and equal treatment to all citizens.

questions.question: Which ethical principle prevents public officers from accepting bribes?
questions.explanation: Integrity requires that civil servants reject bribes and act honestly in official duties.

questions.question: Which civil service principle requires the disclosure of assets by public officers?
questions.explanation: Accountability requires that public officers declare their assets before and after service.

questions.question: Which civil service principle ensures that information is shared openly and not hidden?
questions.explanation: Transparency ensures openness in government dealings and reduces secrecy.

questions.question: Which ethical obligation prohibits civil servants from disclosing classified information?
questions.explanation: Confidentiality ensures sensitive information is not disclosed unlawfully.

questions.question: Which principle ensures that civil servants act with professionalism and respect?
questions.explanation: Professionalism requires that civil servants conduct themselves with competence and respect.

questions.question: Which value ensures civil servants are held answerable for their actions?
questions.explanation: Accountability ensures public officers are responsible for their actions and decisions.

questions.question: Which principle requires civil servants to avoid favoritism in hiring and promotions?
questions.explanation: Impartiality ensures fair recruitment and promotions without favoritism.

questions.question: Which ethical principle prohibits civil servants from leaking government secrets?
questions.explanation: Confidentiality prevents civil servants from disclosing sensitive government information.

questions.question: Which civil service principle requires civil servants to avoid discrimination in service delivery?
questions.explanation: Impartiality means providing fair and equal treatment to all citizens.

questions.question: Which ethical obligation requires civil servants to respect the rule of law in all activities?
questions.explanation: The rule of law ensures civil servants act within the law and uphold justice.

questions.question: Which ethical obligation prohibits civil servants from taking part in partisan politics?
questions.explanation: Impartiality requires that civil servants remain neutral and avoid partisan politics.

questions.question: Which value ensures that civil servants use public funds for their intended purpose?
questions.explanation: Accountability requires that civil servants use public resources responsibly for their intended purposes.

questions.question: Which principle requires civil servants to avoid conflicts between official duty and private interests?
questions.explanation: Integrity requires avoiding conflicts of interest and maintaining fairness in official duties.

questions.question: Which constitutional body ensures ethical conduct in public service?
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct Bureau ensures compliance with ethical standards for public officers.

questions.question: Which ethical principle demands that civil servants avoid actions that could discredit the service?
questions.explanation: Professionalism requires civil servants to conduct themselves in a way that upholds the reputation of the service.

questions.question: Which principle ensures public confidence in the civil service?
questions.explanation: Transparency, impartiality, and accountability collectively build public trust in the civil service.

questions.question: Which ethical principle requires civil servants to be answerable for their decisions?
questions.explanation: Accountability requires public officers to be answerable for their decisions and actions.

questions.question: Which ethical principle requires prompt and efficient service delivery?
questions.explanation: Efficiency requires civil servants to deliver services quickly, effectively, and without waste.

questions.question: Which ethical value discourages corruption and promotes fairness?
questions.explanation: Integrity discourages corruption and requires fairness and honesty in service delivery.

questions.question: Which principle ensures that civil servants are responsible stewards of public resources?
questions.explanation: Accountability ensures civil servants use public resources responsibly and answer for their use.

questions.question: Which civil service principle ensures openness in government contracting processes?
questions.explanation: Transparency ensures openness and fairness in government contracting and procurement.

questions.question: Which ethical principle requires civil servants to avoid personal bias in decision-making?
questions.explanation: Impartiality requires decisions to be made without personal bias or favoritism.

questions.question: Which ethical principle ensures that civil servants keep government information secure?
questions.explanation: Confidentiality ensures that sensitive government information is kept secure and not disclosed unlawfully.

questions.question: Which principle ensures fairness in the treatment of colleagues and subordinates?
questions.explanation: Professionalism ensures fair and respectful treatment of colleagues and subordinates.

questions.question: Which ethical principle ensures judicious use of scarce public resources?
questions.explanation: Efficiency requires prudent use of scarce public resources to maximize benefits.

questions.question: Which ethical principle requires civil servants to be answerable for their decisions?
questions.explanation: Accountability requires public officers to be answerable for their decisions and actions.

questions.question: Which ethical principle prohibits favoritism in public service?
questions.explanation: Impartiality prohibits favoritism and requires fair service to all citizens.

questions.question: Which principle ensures that civil servants manage public funds responsibly?
questions.explanation: Accountability ensures responsible and transparent management of public funds.

questions.question: Which ethical value requires that decisions are taken openly and justifiably?
questions.explanation: Transparency ensures openness in decision-making and builds public trust.

questions.question: Which principle is fundamental to civil service recruitment and promotion?
questions.explanation: Recruitment and promotion in the civil service should be based on merit, fairness and transparency.

subcategories.name: Anti-Corruption
subcategories.description: Agencies, laws, and measures to combat corruption in the public service.

questions.question: Which anti-corruption agency focuses on investigating economic and financial crimes?
questions.explanation: The EFCC investigates and prosecutes financial crimes such as fraud, money laundering, and corruption.

questions.question: Which agency is empowered to investigate corrupt practices in public institutions?
questions.explanation: The Independent Corrupt Practices Commission (ICPC) investigates corrupt practices in public institutions.

questions.question: Which Nigerian law established the ICPC?
options: Corrupt Practices and Other Related Offences Act 2000
questions.explanation: The ICPC was established under the Corrupt Practices and Other Related Offences Act 2000.

questions.question: Which Nigerian agency is mandated to investigate cases of financial integrity among public officers?
questions.explanation: The EFCC investigates financial crimes such as fraud, embezzlement, and illicit enrichment.

questions.question: Which agency investigates and prosecutes corruption in public procurement?
questions.explanation: The ICPC is empowered to investigate corruption in public procurement and contracts.

questions.question: Which agency is empowered to ensure compliance with Nigeria’s anti-corruption policies?
questions.explanation: The ICPC ensures compliance with Nigeria’s anti-corruption policies and laws.

questions.question: Which agency investigates cases of gratification or bribery in government institutions?
questions.explanation: The ICPC investigates cases of bribery and gratification involving public officers.

questions.question: Which act makes bribery and corruption criminal offences in Nigeria?
options: Corrupt Practices and Other Related Offences Act 2000
questions.explanation: The Corrupt Practices and Other Related Offences Act criminalizes bribery and corruption.

questions.question: Which Nigerian agency is mandated to promote ethical values in public service?
questions.explanation: The CCB promotes ethical values and monitors compliance by public officers.

subcategories.name: Conflict of Interest
subcategories.description: Situations where personal interests conflict with official duties and how to avoid them.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of conflict of interest in the civil service?
questions.explanation: Conflict of interest occurs when a public officer awards contracts or takes decisions for personal benefit.

questions.question: Which misconduct involves using an official position to obtain undue advantage?
questions.explanation: Abuse of office occurs when an official uses their position for personal advantage or gain.

questions.question: Which misconduct involves using office resources for private business?
questions.explanation: Abuse of office includes using official resources for personal or private business.

questions.question: Which misconduct involves unauthorized use of official vehicles?
questions.explanation: Unauthorized use of official vehicles constitutes abuse of office and misconduct.

subcategories.name: Misconduct
subcategories.description: Types of misconduct under Public Service Rules and their consequences.

questions.question: Which of these is considered misconduct under the Public Service Rules?
questions.explanation: Corruption is classified as misconduct and attracts disciplinary measures under the Public Service Rules.

questions.question: Which type of misconduct involves deliberate misrepresentation of facts?
questions.explanation: Falsehood is misconduct involving intentional misrepresentation of facts.

questions.question: Which civil service rule prohibits acceptance of double remuneration?
questions.explanation: The Public Service Rules prohibit public officers from receiving double pay from government sources.

questions.question: Which misconduct involves divulging official secrets without authorization?
questions.explanation: Divulging official information without authorization is a form of serious misconduct.

questions.question: Which misconduct involves unauthorized absence from duty?
questions.explanation: Absenteeism is misconduct where a public officer fails to report to duty without permission.

questions.question: Which misconduct involves falsifying records for personal advantage?
questions.explanation: Forgery is misconduct involving falsification of official records.

questions.question: Which misconduct involves deliberate non-compliance with lawful orders?
questions.explanation: Insubordination is deliberate refusal to comply with lawful orders from superiors.

subcategories.name: General Ethics
subcategories.description: General questions on ethics, civil service handbook, and related topics.

questions.question: Which document sets out the duties, responsibilities and conduct of civil servants?
questions.explanation: The Public Service Rules set out terms and conditions, conduct, duties and responsibilities for civil servants.

questions.question: What does 'Estacode' relate to in civil service practice?
questions.explanation: Estacode is the set of rules on official travel and allowances in the civil/public service.

questions.question: Which of the following is a best-practice principle for official correspondence retention?
options: Keep both incoming and outgoing official correspondence for the prescribed retention period
Keep only electronic copies without backups
questions.explanation: Good records management requires retention of official incoming and outgoing correspondence for specified retention schedules and proper archiving.
